I agree that programs should obtain parental permission. 
 
 I think a clinic field trip can be very educational for students entering (or already in) adolescence. Kids are hands-on, especially a high risk group. So it can be very important for them to see first-hand that there's more than meets the eye to a sexual relationship. There are health, pregnancy, family, and ethical issues. Going on-site can really drive some points home. Rather than just telling students about it. Such a visit, with demonstrators too, can also be a basis for debate and discussion about issues like abortion. Getting students to consider what their opinions on these subjects really are, and that certain choices can lead to much bigger considerations down the road. Such a visit can also help students learn more about science, health, and related occupations they might be interested in.
 
 So I support students having lots of information here as long as the parents are o.k. And as long as the information is presented in a responsible and respectful context, and so that the students can actually use it.
 
 I think it's important to remember that health education is not agreeing with sexual relationships outside of marriage. Even people getting married need to know about these things.
 
 We need a society of informed persons and realistic (and responsible) health education is part of getting there.

We need a society of informed persons and realistic (and responsible) health education is part of getting there.

Depending on circumstances this can kill them or ruin their futures. Well intended parents often make this mistake, I do not really know why. But ignorance is definitely NOT bliss in the end.

 In other words the decision of when a child is ready to learn this stuff, what particular viewpoint those children should be taught, and where those children should learn that viewpoint are all matters that should be decided by the State, rather than by the parents.
 
 What institutions like Planned Parenthood wish to do is drive a wedge between the parent/child relationship so that they can present themselves as the entity with the child's best interest in mind. The problem is that this is objectively not so. Planned Parenthood has a financial stake in counseling sessions, and stand to make money on every abortion they successfully convince anyone--including a minor--to have. And they do target minors.

Its those of any stripe who wish to impose their will on others (including parents at the extremes) that represent a danger to the freedom of others to make their own choices in life. Freedom is not free and individuals and their social systems have to fight to maintain human rights.

Some non-Christians who are religious also offer morality and good judgment. And having a group of students take a field trip to various social resources like planned parenthood (along with others) is not forcing anyone into "lockstep" at all. After all its not like the parents are locked away and no longer influence their children. They can teach them whatever values they choose. On the other hand the parents should not and cannot restrict their childs sources of information from which to draw decisions ONLY to the parents. We are all of us embedded in larger communities than our families. Insisting on isolation of ones children from the world they live in beyond the family bounds is harmful to the children and its not possible to accomplish in practice.

 Plus, with t.v., peers and all, without adults providing this information, kids easily get all wrong information about sex, learning it "on the street." 
 
 I think the mistake among parents is that they can shield children from information. They cannot. But they can take steps to ensure that information is accurate.

One characteristic of high risk groups is that no one in the family has usually talked to them about sex (outside of popular culture, peers).
 
 Parents should start talking to their children about sex early on in an age-appropriate way. That makes other information, by the time they are hitting adolescence, much easier to impart, and in a relationship where it is not uncomfortable to talk about such things. 
 
 But sometimes the parents don't want to talk about sex at all, and they don't want the schools to talk about it, but believe me, the kids are talking about it. And some of the info they're getting is very mixed up, and at great risk to their lives and futures.
 
 A network t.v. scene I just loved recently showed two persons who barely knew each other, throwing inhibition to the wind, to have sex on a beach, with no condoms. I wager future episodes will not show either of them discovering they are now HIV positive.

 Ha! That's the catch ain't it. These health education classes can take something so exciting and ruin it rapidly with cold blooded biology and a sterile visit to a doctor's office to see where one could be later on. Or one and their partner should go beforehand. Or hear the kind of inconvenient conversations *hip* people really have before *getting down*.
 
 
Sin in the sand and lust in the dust are very old human fantasies I would suppose.

 
 Hey, I won't knock the fantasy. But show me an American youth with hormones pitching in, who watches this kind of television, talks to other kids, and whose parents don't talk with them about sex, and I wager there's someone who needs to be sitting in classes with a health educator.

It depends on the purpose of the field trip. As part of social services available in a community, sounds o.k., but it may be a tough one to pull off. Or as part of a world religions class where students are visiting different religious places including synagogues, buddhist temples, other christian churches, and mosques, sounds o.k. too, to me. Planned Parenthood has a financial stake in counseling sessions, and stand to make money on every abortion they successfully convince anyone--including a minor--to have. And they do target minors.

 
 Sure, Planned Parenthood is all about profit. That's why they have the tax exempt 501(3)(c) designation. That's why they have sliding scale fees for their services to those who need low cost health care. And that's why the cost of abortions is largely unchanged in the last 20-30 years.

Sure, Planned Parenthood is all about profit. That's why they have the tax exempt 501(3)(c) designation. That's why they have sliding scale fees for their services to those who need low cost health care. And that's why the cost of abortions is largely unchanged in the last 20-30 years.

 
 You do know that tax law doesn't work as a viable argument against most people.
 
 Most people have no idea what a 501(3)(c) is much less the long list of what they can't do.
